QuoteText: Explain to me how if the earth is only 6,000 years old, the world wouldn't work.
ResponseText: Well, two things spring to mind: 1) Radioactive decay over 4.5 billion years compressed into 6000 years would generate how much heat? 2) Techtonic activity over 4 billion years compressed into 6000 years would generate how much heat?

QuoteText: If I was a Christian I couldn't believe in a massive lying God.
ResponseText: You know, Descartes actually made an argument about this in his Meditations over 350 years ago. According to his argument, God has given us the power of reason. He has given us strong inclinations to trust it, and He has given us good evidence that trusting it works out well for us. Perhaps most crucially, He hasn't given us any way to determine that reason is systematically wrong about things. So if our reason does systematically lead us into error, despite all our inclinations to use it, then God would be (in Descartes' words) a "deceiver" for having given it to us in the first place. But deception, he further argues, is entirely incompatible with God's power and goodness. Hence, God cannot be a deceiver, and we ought to trust our reason. Why creationists are so opposed to "natural reason" -- which to a believer is a gift from God -- is really puzzling. For despite the implications (as spelled out by Descartes), they really do seem to think that it's fundamentally flawed. Just look at all Archie's comments belittling my reliance upon "human intellect," for example.
